NewsDetail.Author: Suzette Gee
NewsDetail.BodyCopy:
Next semester, I look forward to leading a teaching group on "Writing to Learn." The group will focus on how writing can be used in different subject areas and in different stages of learning. The group will determine areas of interest to study throughout the semester and will meet Thursday's at 1:00 in MC 385.

 

The topics can be organized into the various stages of the learning model: Prepare, Teach One Another, Ponder and Prove. Possible topics for the Prepare stage include journals, active reading methods, summaries, mapping, one minute essays, double-entry journals, and learning logs. We can also explore how to assess these types of activities and how to use tools such as wiki or discussion board.

 

In the Teach One Another stage, we could explore small group writing/thinking exercises which can be done in class and how to carry out peer reviews. Finally, in the Ponder/Prove stage, we can consider how to make formal writing assignments, create grading rubrics, and how to assess writing.

 

Clearly, there are a great number of topics we can explore and the group will be responsible to choose the focus. I look forward to meeting with those who are interested in these topics. My graduate work in rhetoric and composition and my current doctoral work have familiarized me with many resources in these different areas which I would love to share. Please contact me if you are interested in participating next semester. gees@byui.edu 

 

 

The short break for the Thanksgiving holiday gives us a chance to catch our breath and maybe catch up on some work that is more difficulty to get to while running from class to class.  In that spirit, we will be offering a

 

Learning Model in Action Workshop on Tuesday, November 24th at 8:30 am.

 

The topic of the workshop is

 

Building Best Practices into your I-Learn Site

 

We will be working in a computer lab so you can actually spend the time cleaning up and restructuring aspects of course for next semester.  We will cover issues like

 

  • Central Organizing Principles
  • Student Interface
  • Linking to assignments from a calendar
  • Branding
  • Customizing the Navigation Menu
  • Embedding multi-media
  • And much more

 

The room location will depend on the number of interested participants, so please RSVP via email to Devan Barker (barkerde@byui.edu) and you will receive a confirmation with the location information.
